name: EIA Commercial Electricity Rate Benchmark
description: The U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA) provides authoritative data on the average price of electricity for commercial customers, published monthly on a state-by-state basis. This serves as a primary benchmark for estimating and comparing electricity expenses.
impact_per_sf: Typically $1.50 - $4.00 per square foot annually, but varies significantly by location, building use, and climate.
expandable_bullets: The 'price per kilowatt-hour' (kWh) is the key metric. As of early 2024, state averages for commercial customers range from ~9 cents/kWh in states like Idaho to over 25 cents/kWh in states like Hawaii and California.
Actual business costs are also driven by 'demand charges' (based on peak electricity usage) and 'time-of-use' (TOU) rates, which are not reflected in the simple average rate.
This benchmark is essential for projecting operating expenses for a new location or evaluating the energy cost burden of an existing property.
action_required: Review the latest 'Electric Power Monthly' report from EIA.gov to find your state's average commercial rate.
Examine your actual utility bills to understand your specific rate structure, including demand charges and TOU pricing.
Consult your utility provider's official rate tariff for detailed pricing schedules applicable to your business type.

name: ISO Public Protection Classification (PPC) Program
description: The Insurance Services Office (ISO) evaluates municipal fire-protection services in communities across the U.S. and assigns a PPC rating from 1 (best) to 10. Insurance companies use this rating as a primary factor in setting commercial property insurance premiums.
expandable_bullets: The score is based on a comprehensive evaluation of the local fire department (50%), water supply system (40%), and emergency communication services (10%).

A lower PPC rating (e.g., a Class 2) signifies a lower risk of catastrophic fire loss to underwriters, which can translate directly to significantly lower insurance premiums compared to a property in a high-rated area (e.g., a Class 8).
This is a key example of how a property's specific location, entirely outside the control of the business owner, directly impacts operating expenses.
action_required: Ask your commercial insurance broker to provide the specific PPC rating for your property's address.
Use this information as a critical point of comparison when evaluating new locations for expansion or relocation.
When getting insurance quotes, ensure the broker is using the correct and most up-to-date PPC rating for your location to get an accurate premium.
